name: The Maritime Hotel

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed March 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We stayed at The Maritime for 3 nights over Easter and had the best stay at a NYC hotel I have had in many years. I am a particular fan of this hotel's aesthetic - the japanese feel, great fit out, fabrics, low lighting etc - so I was won over from the very beginning. The rooms aren't huge and for a couple of men, sharing the smaller than king size bed was something I had to get used to. But the rooms are very efficient, well designed, beautifully fitted out and with great toiletries in the bathrooms. The Japanese restaurant (Matsuri) was so popular we could not get a table - this was a great disappointment for us so make sure you book. We did order from the restaurant menu in our room so make sure you don't miss the black cod! La Bottega did a great breakfast and also has a great feel.
reviews.title: Excellent service and attention to details

likes.liked: — Vibe and feel of the hotel, location, restaurants and bars, room fit out and toiletries
likes.disliked: — I wish they had king size beds

reviews.text: I just thought the hotel was so refreshing and superlative in every way. The staff were great and just so friendly also. Its a great part of town and only one block from the ACE and L trains at 14th street - the key to the city on public transport. There are many local restaurants nearby, great shops and local bars too - avoid the over run Pastis and head for the Fatty Crab on Hudson Street.
reviews.title: Laid back boutique who gets the formula right every time

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed January 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Forget midtown and Tribeca/Soho - this hotel is v cool and in a great area. You won't be at all disappointed!
reviews.title: Great time at the Maritime

reviews.text: This was my second stay at The Maritime and I must say that it is a hotel that I have really warmed to. Initial impressions may not be a glitzy as some hotels in New York - but once you settle in, the hotel is a fantastic choice. Firstly the rates are excellent - very good value for money. The hotel also has a good location - close to Chelsea, Meatpacking District and The Village - so good for shopping, nightlife, restaurants and central for getting around the city. Rooms are small with queen size beds (but this is the norm in NYC), but well designed with lovely bed linen, tv/dvd/stereo, complimentary wi-fi, fantastic shower (but no tub) and the best mini bar selection you will ever come across. There are two restaurant choices. Matsui is one of the best Japanese restaurants in the city and La Botega offers a good breakfast (love the oatmeal and latte) and a nice selection of Italian cuisine. The full menu from both restaurants are also available on Room Service, which makes a pleasant change from the 'club sandwich & ceasar salad' options that so many hotels offer. There is a also a nice 'laid back' bar with a DJ at the weekends (not the most happening place in town, but a good vibe). Staff are very friendly - a little informal at times, but it suits the style of the place. All in all, this is a great option for both a leisure trip, or low maintenence business traveller. Thumbs up for The Maritime.
reviews.title: Love the Maritime

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed November 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We stayed at The Maritime just after New Year's this year for a week. Everything was lovely, spotlessly clean, helpful and friendly staff. The room was small but adequate. Lovely big bathroom with robes and lovely fluffy towels.
reviews.title: Great things come in small packages!
THE most professional hotel customer service I have had anywhere!!
reviews.text: This review of the beautiful and unique property, the Maritime Hotel, is somewhat late in being posted, but I thought with the latest round of hotel recommendations being given in New York CIty, I would get mine written and posted.
Our visit was for my 48th Birthday in mid July, 2007. After reading numerous reviews for a special place for this birthday, I finally settled on the Maritime.
reviews.title: Cool look, not so good service

reviews.text: One month before my big day, we made the initial reservation. We planned on arriving on Thursday and leaving on Monday morning. I bypassed the computer and called the hotel directly as I wanted to be sure that a nice room with the best view be held for me.
reviews.title: Nice touches

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The phone call was taken by a wonderfully polite and professional young man whose name now escapes me. He told me of their available rooms and we settled on a basic king room. Although I had thought of booking a suite, it occured to me that we had made so many plans that we would cut back where we could to make sure we had not only enough cash but energy as well to make it through the long weekend celebration.
reviews.title: Loved the Maritime!

reviews.text: A few days before we left for New York, my SO called and confirmed our reservation and all seemed to be in place.
reviews.title: Have stayed there 4x--love The Maritime

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed July 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The Martime falls into the category of hotels that can be easily underestimated from the outside. Firstly, it still resembles the former port authourity building it once housed and the entrance is small and dark with quite a few steep steps up (not sure what wheelchair users would do). The lobby is dark but decorated with great thought and attention and the whole hotel retains the nautical theme throughout. Although the hotel is small, it's a real boutique and rather eccentric - refreshingly it has none of the hall marks of a NYC hotel chain. The rooms are small - the kind that you can walk in, walk around the bed and that's pretty much it, but this is NY and one starts to accept that space is a major extravagance in this city. However the room is well appointed and has a great comfortable bed. All the essentials are provided plus the power shower is pretty refreshing. Loved the alternative toiletries.
reviews.title: Individual and true to it's image....lovely little find

likes.liked: — The hotel restaurants, location, boutique hotel theme

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: La Bottega, the Italian restaurant is excellent, serving great breakfast and lunch at good prices. Matsui, the downstairs Japanese restaurant is superb and the sashimi was fresh and well cut. The restaurant itself is massive and feels like being in Tokyo. The gym is pretty small, slightly airless and has one running machine and bike and some free weights - to be honest, I never met anyone else in the gym so it was fine for me, although the basement floor is stuffy. At the weekends, actually from Thursday night onwards, the hotel is ovetaken by crowds of scantily dressed 18 year olds partying with friends. This is fine, but the associated noise is ridiculously loud and at 4am I could still hear revellers departing the hotel club, Hiro. The plughole that's provided by management is a good temporary solution to the noise, but it is large and cumbersome and nearly knocked me on the bed when I tried to place it at the window. Once attached, the room does indeed become soundproof but also becomes pitch black resembles being in a bunker. However, that is the most negative I can get about the Martime, as the overall hotel is a real gem. The staff are friendly and accomodating. I would recommend this hotel to anyone who likes the nightlife of a city, but also wants something a little different. If I compare this hotel to the pretentious and gauche Hotel Gansevoort down the road, I think Martime wins hands down.
reviews.title: A bit of heaven in NYC

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: From the moment we walked into the cool (yet warm & friendly) hotel lobby our stay at the Maritime Hotel was superb. Literally, every single hotel/restaurant staff we encountered was so friendly and nice, we began to wonder if we were really in NY. We were impressed with the lobby, but blown away by our room. It felt like a deluxe cabin on a fantasy version of the QEII with an oversized stateroom and window overlooking the ocean of the city. Our bed and bedding were amongst the most comfortable we have ever experienced. Both restaurants on the premises were phenomenal and reasonably priced (for New York). And please don't forget the Lychee Martini...heavenly! I can't say enough about the hospitality, accommodations, and fabulous location of this hotel. Seriously, you don't even need to leave the premises to have a relaxing, luxurious vacation.
reviews.title: Great Hotel, Great Location, Great Value!

reviews.text: We stayed at the Maritime for the first 3 days of a 5 day trip. The second two days were spent at 60 Thompson which although equally good, charged nearly twice the price and I think there are far better ways to spend the money in NYC!
reviews.title: THE Place to Stay in Manhattan

likes.disliked: — nothing - it was so damn superb!

reviews.text: The Maritime is cool without the pretension of much of it's competition. Design conscious yet comfortable with staff that are friendly and helpful but not overbearing. The bar was buzzing and provided a great meeting place, particularly the fab outside area beautifully lit with lanterns from dusk. Clearly popular with a hip media crowd and numerous models could be found mooching around the lobby.
reviews.title: Great hotel fantastic location
Nice and Trendy
reviews.text: Had my second stay at the Maritime. First one was about 2 years ago. Both experiences were excellent. I like the design of this hotel. It's upscale and casual at the same time, with an elegant lobby. The Maritime takes inspiration from "cruise ships" and executes relatively well overall. The rooms are somewhat small, but they are reasonable by NYC standards. They are clean, with comfy beds and nice amenities. What sets this hotel apart is the trendy location, nightlife and population. Lots of good looking people, rather young guests (most are in their 30s I would say), the bars inside or outside (patio) are always crowded and the music is good. It's trendy but still relaxed and positive, without the attitude you can find at other places.

reviews.title: very pleasantly surprised
reviews.text: Just come back from 5 nights here and it was great. I usually stay in The Gansevoort (where the staff are appalling), but it was full. This place had a great rate (395) so I was a little worried about the rooms etc, but completely unnecessarily. Rooms are a reasonable size for NYC and very well done out. Room service was snappy and delicious. Staff were very friendly and the bar had one of the best djs I heard whilst I was here (and a great jukebox). I would say the atmosphere reminded me a lot of the West Holywood Standard in terms of being pretty relaxed but professional. Overall I was very impressed and would def come back.

reviews.title: Cool Concept & Design. Good Hotel.
reviews.text: This is very good a hip & trendy boutique hotel. The design & concept is fun & well thought out. You really feel as though your in a ship. For small rooms, they sure did have a lot of attention to details. Great Mini bar with lots of un snacks! The staff was really nice (minus one woman working at concierege one evening), food was great @ La Bottega (although service was awful). Beds were super comfy & being that the hotel was covered in a dark Marine Blue & warm woods, it really promoted a good night's sleep (although stepping out into the daylight was a shock to the system)!

reviews.title: Excellent service
reviews.text: Just had the pleasure of staying at the Maritime this past weekend. The service of the entire staff was excellent, room service was fast, the doormen were friendly, the front desk was very accommodating. The hotel has such a great realxing feel to it. Great bar downstairs for a nightcap! Rooms were nicely done and roomy enough for NYC.

reviews.title: nice hotel in trendy area
reviews.text: I stayed at the maritime hotel recently and must say that my expectations were met. The young ladies who worked at the front desk were nice and sweet. The bellman was friendly. The lobby was very soothing. The room wasn't large, but was adequate. The bathroom was chic and the amenities were very good quality. Room service was among the best I've ever had. Fast like you would not believe, and the food was very delicious and the price was not steep at all. I recommend this hotel to friends. The price per night was about $350, which isn't too expensive for NYC, but it is still expensive. Book direct with the hotel. Thursday's are a great night to be in this area. The club downstaairs in the hotel was very hip, the DJ was very good.

description: Hotel resembles white cruise ship with portholes overlooking Ninth Avenue - West Chelsea neighborhood - 4 blocks to Chelsea Piers.
